title: Solar PV Forecast Today is much less than the sum of half-hour forecasts
body:
Today the Solar Forecast Today label was predicting 0.8Kw, but the half hour forecast PV figures were predicting about 0.25 kWh every half hour over about 8 slots.  Is the slot forecast meant to be the rate of power generation per hour or the amount of power estimated to be generated in the half hour? 

Perhaps one of these has the damping factor applied and not the other.

Incidentally it is not clear what the damping factor does to the estimated solar power generation. If 10Kw of solar power was predicted and the damping factor was 25%, would that mean the corrected estimate was 7.5Kw (percentage reduction) or 2.5Kw (multiplier). The 50% example unfortunately gives the same result for both methods.

I just noticed a strange thing - if I increased the damping factor from 30% to 80% the total amount of power generation predicted on the label increased; I would have expected it to down. The half-hour forecast were unchanged.
author: dqj999

comments.body:
In the latest dev version this is all much-improved; the last release version doesn't have the damping factor applied and there's a couple of other bugs. 

The damping factor might be counter-intuitive - it basically means "use this percentage of the solcast figures". So if you set 80%, then it'll reduce the solcast estimate by 20%. Again, I can probably make this more intuitive, but I'm re-writing it so it's calculated automatically anyway (see #65) - once that's working, you won't need to manually set the damping factor at all (but I might leave it there as a manual override).

I'm not actually using the solcast data to affect the charging algorithm yet, so until that happens, the oddities in the display aren't critical.

I get it - so it's like a de-rating factor. 

BTW Brilliant piece of software. Ticking over very nicely on my 64-bit Pi 3B.
Glad you're liking it. Just pushed a new release with better config set up (uses the Octopus API key and account number) plus a bunch of other new figures. See the release for details
I've found a fix for this issue - one of my calculations was off. Will push a release once some other stuff is ready.
This should be fixed in the next release.

title: Solcast API Calls
body:
I currently have 2 arrays configured in Solcast and use it primarily in a Home Assistant automation and dashboard display. 

I update the dashboard 5 times a day and so that is 10 calls to the API (5 for each array). Since we are limited to 10 API calls per 24 hrs , this means Solis Monitor pinches some of my Home Assistant calls.

I could probably reduce my Home Assistant updates to 3 times per day (6 API calls), so could Solis Monitor survive with 4 calls to the API? It would be up to 4 calls for a single array or 2 calls for twin arrays. 

Would it make sense to parameterise this in the config file?
author: HarryFlatter

comments.body: Okay, next version will have an additional config setting. By default the app will just do one call at 02:13am, but there'll be an option (defaulting to 'off') to have extra calls at 6am and midday, to improve forecasting accuracy, if you have the spare API rate-limit availability.
(Still have to work on the ability to specify multiple solcast API site keys - #52)

Thanks for the update :-).

Since many overnight 'cheap' rates commence at just gone midnight, would it make sense to make that first call at 00:13 so that when you are utilising the forecast data, the app can decide whether or not to action a battery charge based on forecasted solar yield for later that day?

... or parameterise the time of the first call and a yes/no for each of the following 2 calls. That way you can control exactly how many calls will be made (1 or 2 or 3 for single arrays or 2 or 4 or 6 for dual arrays).

Yeah, maybe midnight-ish is better (Solcast gives 97 or so 30-minute forecasts, so that should cover the next day or two). 

I'm reluctant to put too many config options for scheduling etc - it makes the UI more complex and harder to test (we don't want to end up with a UI like the SolisCloud App control screen...). Generally better to be opinionated, and I think midnight as you say will cover the main use-cases.
